Award.AwardTitle: Spatial Conservation and Investment Portfolios to Manage Climate-Related Risk

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This GSS/DRMS project investigates how the theory of efficient financial portfolios can be modified, enriched, and harnessed to manage the nature-conservation risk that climate uncertainty creates. Agencies and conservation groups cannot know exactly which areas will prove to be the best conservation sites in a future warmer climate; this creates the risk that land areas protected today for conservation purposes might not end up being good habitat or hot spots of biodiversity in the future. Scholars of finance have long used portfolio theory to manage financial risk faced by an investor through diversification. Recent research has shown that financial tools could be adapted to the problem of allocating conservation investments between different parts of a conservation planning area to reduce future conservation risk from climate change by spreading conservation lands strategically between multiple areas. However, adapting the science of portfolio theory from finance to conservation is a non-trivial endeavor. To advance that science, this project will develop new spatial conservation-outcome forecasts for the Prairie Pothole Region and construct spatial data sets suitable for spatial portfolio analysis for two other previously studied conservation problems (Eastern birds, Appalachian salamanders). Using the data on those three diverse conservation problems, the researchers will: identify the kinds of problems for which this spatial conservation portfolio diversification is most useful; figure out how to develop a spatial conservation portfolio when information regarding conservation outcomes is only available for a small number of climate scenarios; develop a method of portfolio analysis to guide division of investment between land purchases and management activities that buffer protected areas against warming; and explore whether portfolio analysis can be used by a decision maker who is concerned with several different conservation goals.

This research will yield valuable guidance to government agencies and private conservation groups regarding spatial conservation strategies in the Prairie Pothole Region - sometimes referred to as 'the Duck Factory' - that reduce the risk climate change poses to future waterfowl conservation success. More importantly, this research will develop conservation tools that decision makers wrestling with a wide range of conservation problems can use themselves with climate and ecological forecast data they deem to be sufficiently accurate and that measure the conservation outcomes with which they are most concerned; the tools will help them to allocate conservation investments across space in ways that minimize uncertainty in the outcomes of those investments, increasing the social well-being produced by their expenditures. The grant will train two graduate students at the University of Illinois in spatial analysis and the application of portfolio theory to conservation, and support four female faculty researchers in fields where women are under-represented (two early in their academic careers.) The project will engage and train a diverse group of undergraduate students that represent academic backgrounds across economics, ecology, and geography in a meaningful multidisciplinary research experience. The results will be distributed through journal articles and conference presentations; in addition, the researchers will communicate the results to stakeholders directly through professional contacts in federal agencies and at major land conservation groups such as The Nature Conservancy, Conservation International, and the Environmental Defense Fund.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The impacts of climate change will likely mean that we will not know where high quality habitat or species populations will be in the future. This means that places protected now for nature may fail as sanctuaries in the future as species and ecosystems change location. How can we reduce future uncertainty in conservation outcomes associated with climate change? Financial planners have used diversified portfolios since the 1950s to reduce investment risk; buying many different stocks and a mixture of stocks and bonds makes it less likely that an investor will lose everything if one part of the market fails. A team of economists and ecologists (Amy Ando, Glenn Guntenspergen, Mindy Mallory, and Jennifer Fraterrigo) worked with graduate students and a research fellow (Aparna Howlader, Jennifer Olker, and Samuel Stickley) on a project titled "Spatial Conservation and Investment Portfolios to Manage Climate-Related Risk" which has translated those tools from finance to improve strategies for environmental investments.


The intellectual contributions of this research include several important methodological developments and findings. The team developed computer tools for spatial conservation portfolio planning that identifies portfolios of investments that minimize uncertainty in conservation outcomes when a planner is interested in a single objective (like protecting waterfowl habitat) or more than one objective. This project identified how using conservation portfolio optimization can greatly reduce the cost of buffering protected areas against climate change. Results showed conservation agents how portfolio analysis can take advantage of investments that are robust to climate change and the presence of negative correlations between future outcomes in different parts of the landscape, picking a careful mixture of conservation sites in a landscape that will be effective long into the future. Conservation planners can sometimes benefit from using some of their conservation budget to invest in climate adaptation strategies on the lands they do protect in their portfolio, though there are conditions under which investing in adaptation is not part of the best course of action.


When a planner is interested in multiple objectives (like protecting different kinds of birds), this project found that it is more efficient to optimize a portfolio for multiple conservation objectives jointly; that allows the planner to exploit information about correlations between the things they seek to protect. This analysis yielded other surprising insights. For example, if a planner is interested in environmental goods that have opposite responses to a climate shock in the same place, that is a form of self insurance, and the overall riskiness of putting all your eggs in the best basket (so to speak) is actually quite low. 


This project also produced key knowledge about the effects of climate change on ecosystems at different spatial scales. For example, research on the impact of climate change on Prairie Pothole wetlands revealed that the magnitude and direction of hydrologic responses to climate change depends on whether such change increases or decreases water deficits. There is likely not a universally applicable approach to mitigating climate change impacts on freshwater wetlands across regional aridity gradients, and conservation strategies need to account for aridity‐specific effects of climate change on freshwater wetland ecosystems. Research on montane ecosystems in the southern Appalachians revealed that fine-scale (~3 m2) vegetation structure and topographic patterns strongly modulate large-scale climate patterns. Fine-scale information about the spatial distribution of microclimates will likely be needed to manage and conserve ground-dwelling species like salamanders. A "one size fits all" conservation approach will have limited regional benefit. 


Beyond the immediate intellectual contributions of this research, the work on this project has affected researchers around the world and produced benefits for the general public. This project team has disseminated the research results in professional conferences in the U.S., Europe, and Japan, and they have worked directly with ecologists and economists in several different countries who are incorporating this methodology into their own research. The team has also disseminated the conservation portfolio tools and information about how to use them to scientists at the EPA, the USDA, the World Bank, and conservation NGOs. Conservation portfolio optimization tools are now being used by many conservation scientists as they work on strategies for managing climate uncertainty in conservation planning. This research will help society in the future by producing networks of protected areas and bodies of other environmental investments that are buffered against uncertain threats posed by climate change.
